questions.text: The last symptoms to develop in compartment syndrome is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pulselessness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While all the "5 Ps" are important, pulselessness is the last to develop and represents a critical emergency. Early recognition and treatment of compartment syndrome are crucial to prevent irreversible tissue damage.
  • ➤ While all the "5 Ps" are important, pulselessness is the last to develop and represents a critical emergency.
  • ➤ Early recognition and treatment of compartment syndrome are crucial to prevent irreversible tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly defines Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?

options.label: A
options.text: Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

options.label: B
options.text: Ulnar fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

options.label: C
options.text: Ulnar shaft fracture and disruption of superior radio-ulnar joint

options.label: D
options.text: Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.correct_answer: A. Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
questions.explanation:
Ans.A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The defining characteristic of a Galeazzi fracture-dislocation is the combination of a distal radius fracture and disruption of the DRUJ, with associated TFCC injury.
  • ➤ The defining characteristic of a Galeazzi fracture-dislocation is the combination of a distal radius fracture and disruption of the DRUJ, with associated TFCC injury.

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury to the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lachman Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute knee injuries, especially those involving twisting mechanisms, the Lachman test is the preferred clinical assessment for ACL integrity. Its sensitivity and ease of performance, even in the presence of pain and swelling, make it a crucial diagnostic tool. The twisting motion of the knee is a common way to tear the ACL. The Lachman test is the best way to determine the integrity of the ACL.
  • ➤ In acute knee injuries, especially those involving twisting mechanisms, the Lachman test is the preferred clinical assessment for ACL integrity.
  • ➤ Its sensitivity and ease of performance, even in the presence of pain and swelling, make it a crucial diagnostic tool.
  • ➤ The twisting motion of the knee is a common way to tear the ACL. The Lachman test is the best way to determine the integrity of the ACL.

questions.text: A patient who used to work out regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head, and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gradual onset of pain, aggravated by squatting, is consistent with AVN. The radiographic findings (flattening of the femoral head and subchondral cysts) are classic for AVN.
  • ➤ The gradual onset of pain, aggravated by squatting, is consistent with AVN. The radiographic findings (flattening of the femoral head and subchondral cysts) are classic for AVN.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salter-Harris Type 1 fractures occur at the hypertrophic zone, which is the most vulnerable part of the growth plate.
  • ➤ Salter-Harris Type 1 fractures occur at the hypertrophic zone, which is the most vulnerable part of the growth plate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with difficulty lifting his right foot, resulting in dragging of the foot when walking. He denies pain but notes that he frequently trips and is unable to dorsiflex his right foot. Physical examination reveals weakness in dorsiflexion of the right foot, with intact sensation over the dorsum of the foot and the lateral aspect of the lower leg. There is no history of trauma, and the patient has a history of prolonged sitting with his leg crossed. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Peroneal Nerve Palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inability to dorsiflex the foot is a hallmark of peroneal nerve palsy. The sensory distribution matches the peroneal nerve's innervation. The prolonged leg crossing is a common cause of peroneal nerve compression at the fibular neck. There is also absence of pain and other neurological deficits.
  • ➤ The inability to dorsiflex the foot is a hallmark of peroneal nerve palsy.
  • ➤ The sensory distribution matches the peroneal nerve's innervation.
  • ➤ The prolonged leg crossing is a common cause of peroneal nerve compression at the fibular neck.
  • ➤ There is also absence of pain and other neurological deficits.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with wrist drop following a midshaft humerus fracture. Identify and tell that which of the following splints is most appropriate for management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cock-up splint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cock up splint is best choice for wrist drop (radial nerve palsy). It maintains wrist extension to restore function and prevent complications.
  • ➤ Cock up splint is best choice for wrist drop (radial nerve palsy).
  • ➤ It maintains wrist extension to restore function and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented in clinic with low back pain & stiffness since 2 months. Modified Schober's test done was positive. An X-ray was done as shown in the image. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. It is commonly seen in young males. The patient presents with morning lower back pain and stiffness and decreased lumbar range of motion.
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • ➤ It is commonly seen in young males.
  • ➤ The patient presents with morning lower back pain and stiffness and decreased lumbar range of motion.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about PCL?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the main restraint in posterior drawer test

options.label: B
options.text: It is an extra synovial structure

options.label: C
options.text: It is the main restraint to internal rotation

options.label: D
options.text: It originates from anterolateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the main restraint to internal rotation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the main restraint to internal rotation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The PCL's primary function is to prevent posterior translation of the tibia. While it provides some stability against other movements, it is not the main restraint to internal rotation. The ACL and other structures play a more significant role in limiting internal rotation of the knee.
  • ➤ The PCL's primary function is to prevent posterior translation of the tibia.
  • ➤ While it provides some stability against other movements, it is not the main restraint to internal rotation.
  • ➤ The ACL and other structures play a more significant role in limiting internal rotation of the knee.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with severe, persistent pain and swelling in her right wrist following a distal radius fracture that occurred 6 weeks ago. Despite receiving appropriate treatment and immobilization, the pain has become increasingly intense and burning in nature. She also reports that the wrist has become stiff and swollen, and her skin is now shiny and exhibits an abnormal temperature difference compared to the left wrist. On examination, she has limited range of motion, tenderness to palpation, and allodynia (pain to light touch). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of persistent pain, swelling, skin changes, temperature differences, and allodynia following a distal radius fracture strongly suggests CRPS. The burning nature of the pain is also a classic symptom. CRPS is a known complication of distal radius fractures.
  • ➤ The combination of persistent pain, swelling, skin changes, temperature differences, and allodynia following a distal radius fracture strongly suggests CRPS.
  • ➤ The burning nature of the pain is also a classic symptom.
  • ➤ CRPS is a known complication of distal radius fractures.

questions.text: Bone mineral density screening is recommended after the age of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 65 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rationale is that by 65, a significant proportion of women have experienced enough bone loss to warrant screening and intervention if necessary. This is the age that the risk of osteoporotic fractures increases significantly.
  • ➤ The rationale is that by 65, a significant proportion of women have experienced enough bone loss to warrant screening and intervention if necessary.
  • ➤ This is the age that the risk of osteoporotic fractures increases significantly.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity of the right arm. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with weakness in his right hand. He reports that the symptoms began gradually after he lifted a heavy object at work a few days ago. He complains of difficulty with extending his fingers and wrist, and he notes that his grip strength has decreased significantly. On examination, the patient is unable to extend his wrist or the metacarpophalangeal joints of his thumb and index finger, but he can still extend his elbow. Sensation is intact over the dorsum of the hand. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radial nerve palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical picture of wrist drop, difficulty extending the fingers at the MCP joints, and preserved elbow extension, along with intact dorsal hand sensation, points most strongly towards a radial nerve palsy . The lifting of a heavy object could have potentially compressed or stretched the radial nerve.
  • ➤ The clinical picture of wrist drop, difficulty extending the fingers at the MCP joints, and preserved elbow extension, along with intact dorsal hand sensation, points most strongly towards a radial nerve palsy .
  • ➤ radial nerve palsy
  • ➤ The lifting of a heavy object could have potentially compressed or stretched the radial nerve.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the clinic after a traumatic shoulder dislocation during a rugby match. The patient reports immediate pain and weakness in his shoulder, which has persisted even after the shoulder was reduced. He has difficulty lifting his arm, particularly in overhead positions. On examination, he exhibits weakness in shoulder abduction and external rotation. There is also diminished sensation over the lateral aspect of his upper arm. His biceps and triceps reflexes are normal, and there is no evidence of any motor deficits in the forearm or hand. MRI of the shoulder is unremarkable, and no fractures are seen. Given this presentation, which of the following anatomical structures is most likely responsible for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Axillary Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The axillary nerve is commonly injured during shoulder dislocations, particularly anterior dislocations. The weakness in shoulder abduction and external rotation, along with the sensory deficit over the lateral upper arm, are classic signs of axillary nerve injury. The normal reflexes and forearm/hand motor function help to localize the injury to the axillary nerve.
  • ➤ The axillary nerve is commonly injured during shoulder dislocations, particularly anterior dislocations.
  • ➤ The weakness in shoulder abduction and external rotation, along with the sensory deficit over the lateral upper arm, are classic signs of axillary nerve injury.
  • ➤ The normal reflexes and forearm/hand motor function help to localize the injury to the axillary nerve.

questions.text: What is a radiographic finding that is given below which is characterized by radiating spicules of bone extending outward from a central lesion, often associated with osteosarcoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sun ray appearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sun ray appearance is a highly characteristic radiographic finding of osteosarcoma. It reflects the aggressive nature of the tumor, which stimulates the formation of new bone spicules that radiate outward. This pattern is distinct from other periosteal reactions and bone changes.
  • ➤ The sun ray appearance is a highly characteristic radiographic finding of osteosarcoma.
  • ➤ It reflects the aggressive nature of the tumor, which stimulates the formation of new bone spicules that radiate outward.
  • ➤ This pattern is distinct from other periosteal reactions and bone changes.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The priority in a posterior hip dislocation without fractures is to perform a closed reduction as quickly as possible to minimize the risk of complications. Imaging is important, but it's typically performed after the reduction.
  • ➤ The priority in a posterior hip dislocation without fractures is to perform a closed reduction as quickly as possible to minimize the risk of complications.
  • ➤ Imaging is important, but it's typically performed after the reduction.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after his mother pulled his arm while attempting to lift him. The child refuses to move his left arm and holds it in a slightly flexed position at the elbow. On physical examination, the child is alert and well-appearing but cries when the left elbow is moved. There is no swelling, bruising, or obvious deformity. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the most appropriate management for this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Radial head subluxation (nursemaid’s elbow); closed reduction

options.label: C
options.text: Dislocated elbow; immediate reduction and immobilization

questions.correct_answer: B. Radial head subluxation (nursemaid’s elbow); closed reduction
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Radial Head Subluxation (Nursemaid's Elbow); Closed Reduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The history of arm pulling is a classic mechanism of injury. The child's refusal to move the arm and the lack of significant swelling or deformity are consistent with nursemaid's elbow. Closed reduction is the standard treatment and typically provides immediate relief. The age of the child is also a key factor.
  • ➤ The history of arm pulling is a classic mechanism of injury.
  • ➤ The child's refusal to move the arm and the lack of significant swelling or deformity are consistent with nursemaid's elbow.
  • ➤ Closed reduction is the standard treatment and typically provides immediate relief.
  • ➤ The age of the child is also a key factor.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with knee pain after a football injury. He reports that he was tackled and twisted his knee while it was planted on the ground. On physical examination, there is significant swelling around the knee joint, along with instability when performing the Lachman test. The patient also experiences pain and restricted motion when attempting to extend the knee. Based on the clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) O’Donoghue triad

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mechanism of injury is classic for the O'Donoghue triad. The positive Lachman test confirms an ACL tear. The swelling and restricted motion are consistent with the triad. The combination of ACL injury, with likely MCL and meniscal injury is the most likely.
  • ➤ The mechanism of injury is classic for the O'Donoghue triad.
  • ➤ The positive Lachman test confirms an ACL tear.
  • ➤ The swelling and restricted motion are consistent with the triad.
  • ➤ The combination of ACL injury, with likely MCL and meniscal injury is the most likely.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary healing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary healing, also known as direct healing, occurs when there is minimal or no gap between the fractured bone fragments, and the fracture is rigidly fixed (e.g., with surgical plates and screws).
  • ➤ Primary healing, also known as direct healing, occurs when there is minimal or no gap between the fractured bone fragments, and the fracture is rigidly fixed (e.g., with surgical plates and screws).

questions.text: Which of the following childhood injuries will lead to a fish tail injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Distal humerus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "fish tail" deformity is a specific radiographic finding associated with displaced supracondylar fractures of the distal humerus in children. This is due to the unique anatomy of the distal humerus and the forces involved in these fractures.
  • ➤ The "fish tail" deformity is a specific radiographic finding associated with displaced supracondylar fractures of the distal humerus in children.
  • ➤ This is due to the unique anatomy of the distal humerus and the forces involved in these fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture? Compartment syndrome is rare. Immediate debridement should be done. Tibia is the most common long bone involved. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.correct_answer: B. I, II & III are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An open fracture is a fracture where the bone breaks through the skin, creating an open wound. This exposes the fracture site to the external environment, significantly increasing the risk of infection. Proper management is crucial to minimize complications.
  • ➤ An open fracture is a fracture where the bone breaks through the skin, creating an open wound.
  • ➤ This exposes the fracture site to the external environment, significantly increasing the risk of infection.
  • ➤ Proper management is crucial to minimize complications.

questions.text: In osteoporosis, serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Normal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteoporosis is a disorder of bone structure, not mineral composition in the blood. Serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually normal in osteoporosis. If abnormal levels are present, it suggests other underlying conditions.
  • ➤ Osteoporosis is a disorder of bone structure, not mineral composition in the blood.
  • ➤ Serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually normal in osteoporosis.
  • ➤ If abnormal levels are present, it suggests other underlying conditions.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a high-energy motorcycle accident. He complains of severe pain in his right leg. On examination, there is a large open wound over the anterior aspect of his tibia with exposed bone and gravel contamination. The wound is extensive, and the distal pulses in the right foot are diminished. The skin is pale and cool below the knee, and there is significant deformity of the leg. What is the most likely classification of this injury based on the radiograph and clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gustilo-Anderson Grade 3C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A high-energy open tibial fracture with vascular compromise, fits the criteria for Grade 3C, which has the worst prognosis and often requires urgent surgical intervention.
  • ➤ A high-energy open tibial fracture with vascular compromise, fits the criteria for Grade 3C, which has the worst prognosis and often requires urgent surgical intervention.

questions.text: A suspect of sexual assault of 18 years of age claims to be of 16 years. X-rays of which area can confirm the correct age of the suspect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Knee and wrist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ossification of the wrist and knee is a reliable indicator of whether an individual is 18 years old, as both these areas ossify by that age.
  • ➤ The ossification of the wrist and knee is a reliable indicator of whether an individual is 18 years old, as both these areas ossify by that age.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected if the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Flexor pollicis longus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flexor pollicis longus is the sole muscle responsible for flexing the distal phalanx of the thumb, making it essential for completing the "OK" sign. Damage to this muscle will prevent the patient from performing this action.
  • ➤ The flexor pollicis longus is the sole muscle responsible for flexing the distal phalanx of the thumb, making it essential for completing the "OK" sign.
  • ➤ Damage to this muscle will prevent the patient from performing this action.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in his left knee after a fall during a soccer game. X-rays reveal an epiphyseal injury at the distal femur. Which of the following is the most common complication associated with this type of injury in pediatric patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Growth disturbance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The physis is a delicate structure. Any disruption to it can impair or alter the normal process of bone growth. This can result in: Angular deformities (e.g., valgus or varus deformity). Limb length discrepancies. Premature physeal closure.
  • ➤ The physis is a delicate structure.
  • ➤ Any disruption to it can impair or alter the normal process of bone growth.
  • ➤ This can result in: Angular deformities (e.g., valgus or varus deformity). Limb length discrepancies. Premature physeal closure.
  • ➤ This can result in:
  • ➤ Angular deformities (e.g., valgus or varus deformity). Limb length discrepancies. Premature physeal closure.
  • ➤ Angular deformities (e.g., valgus or varus deformity).
  • ➤ Limb length discrepancies.
  • ➤ Premature physeal closure.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chance fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.
  • ➤ A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with progressive wrist pain and swelling. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Giant Cell Tumour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant Cell Tumor: Lytic lesion extending to the subchondral bone. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst: Expansile, "blown out" appearance with septations. Osteosarcoma: Aggressive bone destruction with periosteal reaction. Chondroblastoma: Lytic lesion with punctate calcifications.
  • ➤ Giant Cell Tumor: Lytic lesion extending to the subchondral bone.
  • ➤ Giant Cell Tumor:
  • ➤ Aneurysmal Bone Cyst: Expansile, "blown out" appearance with septations.
  • ➤ Aneurysmal Bone Cyst:
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma: Aggressive bone destruction with periosteal reaction.
  • ➤ Osteosarcoma:
  • ➤ Chondroblastoma: Lytic lesion with punctate calcifications.
  • ➤ Chondroblastoma:

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:

options.label: A
options.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased response to analgesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pain is the most sensitive indicator of increased compartment pressure. As compartment pressure rises, it compresses nerves and causes severe pain, especially with passive stretching. This pain becomes increasingly difficult to control with analgesia. Therefore, a decreased response to analgesia should be a red flag for compartment syndrome.
  • ➤ Pain is the most sensitive indicator of increased compartment pressure.
  • ➤ As compartment pressure rises, it compresses nerves and causes severe pain, especially with passive stretching.
  • ➤ This pain becomes increasingly difficult to control with analgesia.
  • ➤ Therefore, a decreased response to analgesia should be a red flag for compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Assertion reason: Assertion : Proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. Reason : Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The unique retrograde blood supply of the scaphoid is the critical factor that explains why the proximal pole is so vulnerable to AVN after a fracture. Understanding this anatomical detail is essential for diagnosing and managing scaphoid injuries.
  • ➤ The unique retrograde blood supply of the scaphoid is the critical factor that explains why the proximal pole is so vulnerable to AVN after a fracture.
  • ➤ Understanding this anatomical detail is essential for diagnosing and managing scaphoid injuries.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 2-day history of limping and pain in his right hip. His mother reports that he recently had a mild cold with a runny nose, but his symptoms have improved. The child is afebrile and does not appear to be in acute distress. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the right hip with a reduced range of motion, particularly with internal rotation. The child is reluctant to bear weight on the affected leg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Transient synovitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transient synovitis is the most common cause of hip pain in children aged 3-8 years. It often follows a viral upper respiratory infection (URI), which is consistent with this boy’s recent mild cold.
  • ➤ Transient synovitis is the most common cause of hip pain in children aged 3-8 years.
  • ➤ It often follows a viral upper respiratory infection (URI), which is consistent with this boy’s recent mild cold.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The elevated TRAP level in this patient reflects the increased bone resorption occurring in osteoporosis, which is consistent with the other lab findings and the DEXA scan results.
  • ➤ The elevated TRAP level in this patient reflects the increased bone resorption occurring in osteoporosis, which is consistent with the other lab findings and the DEXA scan results.

questions.text: What is the use of the given instrument?

options.label: B
options.text: To hold bone fragments with traction

options.label: D
options.text: For creating a gap in wound

questions.correct_answer: B. To hold bone fragments with traction
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) To hold bone fragments with traction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The instrument's design (toothed jaws, robust handle) is specifically suited for grasping and manipulating bone fragments. The application of traction is a crucial step in fracture reduction, and reduction forceps are essential tools for this purpose.
  • ➤ The instrument's design (toothed jaws, robust handle) is specifically suited for grasping and manipulating bone fragments.
  • ➤ The application of traction is a crucial step in fracture reduction, and reduction forceps are essential tools for this purpose.

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ankle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior-superior aspect of the calcaneus is susceptible to irritation and pressure, especially from tight-fitting shoes. This irritation can lead to bony enlargement and inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa. The Achilles tendon, which inserts onto the calcaneus, can also contribute to the symptoms.
  • ➤ The posterior-superior aspect of the calcaneus is susceptible to irritation and pressure, especially from tight-fitting shoes.
  • ➤ This irritation can lead to bony enlargement and inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa.
  • ➤ The Achilles tendon, which inserts onto the calcaneus, can also contribute to the symptoms.

questions.text: True statements in view of septic arthritis are: a. Widening of joint space is there. b. Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children and neonate. c. Incision and drainage is frequently required. d. Kocher criteria used to differentiate from transient synovitis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Septic arthritis is a bacterial infection of the joint that leads to inflammation, joint destruction, and significant morbidity if not treated promptly.
  • ➤ Septic arthritis is a bacterial infection of the joint that leads to inflammation, joint destruction, and significant morbidity if not treated promptly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with persistent pain and swelling in his left foot for the past 3 months. He reports that the pain has been gradually worsening, and he notices an open wound on the bottom of his foot that has been draining purulent material intermittently. He has had multiple prior episodes of foot infections, and despite antibiotic treatment, the wound has not healed. On examination, there is a foul-smelling wound with surrounding erythema, and the patient has tenderness over the metatarsal bones. X-rays reveal bone sclerosis and cortical thickening in the affected area. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Diabetic neuropathy with a foot ulcer

questions.correct_answer: D. Diabetic neuropathy with a foot ulcer
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diabetic neuropathy with a foot ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While the patient clearly has features of chronic osteomyelitis (as a complication), the root cause and the overall clinical picture, especially the presence of a non-healing, chronically infected ulcer in a diabetic patient, are best summarized by Diabetic neuropathy with a foot ulcer . The osteomyelitis is a severe complication of the diabetic foot ulcer. Therefore, option D describes the overarching condition and the underlying pathology that sets the stage for all the observed symptoms and signs.
  • ➤ While the patient clearly has features of chronic osteomyelitis (as a complication), the root cause and the overall clinical picture, especially the presence of a non-healing, chronically infected ulcer in a diabetic patient, are best summarized by Diabetic neuropathy with a foot ulcer .
  • ➤ Diabetic neuropathy with a foot ulcer
  • ➤ The osteomyelitis is a severe complication of the diabetic foot ulcer.
  • ➤ Therefore, option D describes the overarching condition and the underlying pathology that sets the stage for all the observed symptoms and signs.

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints

options.label: D
options.text: Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of symmetrical polyarthritis, morning stiffness, sparing of the DIP joints, ulnar deviation, and the specific joint involvement strongly suggests Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • ➤ The combination of symmetrical polyarthritis, morning stiffness, sparing of the DIP joints, ulnar deviation, and the specific joint involvement strongly suggests Rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on this X-ray.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Patella fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patella fracture occurs when there is a break in the patella, usually due to direct trauma (such as a fall or a direct blow to the knee) or indirect trauma (such as a sudden, forceful contraction of the quadriceps muscle).
  • ➤ A patella fracture occurs when there is a break in the patella, usually due to direct trauma (such as a fall or a direct blow to the knee) or indirect trauma (such as a sudden, forceful contraction of the quadriceps muscle).

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a fracture of the shaft of the femur is placed in the following splint, which supports the leg in an elevated position with traction. Identify the splint.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bohler-Braun splint is specifically designed for femoral shaft fractures and other lower extremity injuries where elevation and traction are necessary. It provides the necessary support and alignment to facilitate healing and reduce complications. It is superior to a Thomas splint, when elevation is needed.
  • ➤ The Bohler-Braun splint is specifically designed for femoral shaft fractures and other lower extremity injuries where elevation and traction are necessary.
  • ➤ It provides the necessary support and alignment to facilitate healing and reduce complications.
  • ➤ It is superior to a Thomas splint, when elevation is needed.

questions.text: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low grade fever. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fat embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Femur fractures are a significant risk factor for fat embolism. The timing (2 days post-surgery) is consistent with the typical onset of FES. The symptoms of sudden shortness of breath, and low-grade fever are classic signs of FES.
  • ➤ Femur fractures are a significant risk factor for fat embolism.
  • ➤ The timing (2 days post-surgery) is consistent with the typical onset of FES.
  • ➤ The symptoms of sudden shortness of breath, and low-grade fever are classic signs of FES.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought in with bowlegs, and the wrist x-ray revealed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickets is the most accurate cause for bowlegs. The X-ray of the wrists reveals cupping, fraying and splaying phenomenon of the bones, which are characteristic of vitamin D deficiency rickets.
  • ➤ Rickets is the most accurate cause for bowlegs.
  • ➤ The X-ray of the wrists reveals cupping, fraying and splaying phenomenon of the bones, which are characteristic of vitamin D deficiency rickets.

questions.text: True statements about fracture shaft of femur: More commonly in elderly. Easily managed with Gallow’s traction in elderly. Associated with pulmonary complications. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) c & d are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fracture of the shaft of the femur is a serious injury, commonly seen in young adults due to high-energy trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accidents) and in elderly individuals due to falls. Elderly patients are more prone to hip fractures, specifically intertrochanteric and femoral neck fractures, due to osteoporosis. Gallow's traction is primarily used in young children (< 2 years old) due to their lower body weight and ability to tolerate the traction. It is not appropriate for elderly patients due to their increased risk of complications from prolonged immobilization, such as pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis, and pressure ulcers.
  • ➤ A fracture of the shaft of the femur is a serious injury, commonly seen in young adults due to high-energy trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accidents) and in elderly individuals due to falls.
  • ➤ Elderly patients are more prone to hip fractures, specifically intertrochanteric and femoral neck fractures, due to osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Gallow's traction is primarily used in young children (< 2 years old) due to their lower body weight and ability to tolerate the traction.
  • ➤ It is not appropriate for elderly patients due to their increased risk of complications from prolonged immobilization, such as pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis, and pressure ulcers.

questions.text: What is the most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The endplates of the vertebral bodies are richly vascularized, making them susceptible to hematogenous spread of tuberculosis. The disc space is also relatively avascular, which makes it difficult for the body's immune system to fight off infection once it reaches this area. This explains why the infection tends to progress from the vertebral body endplates to the disc space.
  • ➤ The endplates of the vertebral bodies are richly vascularized, making them susceptible to hematogenous spread of tuberculosis.
  • ➤ The disc space is also relatively avascular, which makes it difficult for the body's immune system to fight off infection once it reaches this area.
  • ➤ This explains why the infection tends to progress from the vertebral body endplates to the disc space.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets?

options.label: D
options.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.correct_answer: D. High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The core problem in nutritional rickets is the body's inability to absorb and utilize calcium and phosphorus effectively. The body compensates by increasing PTH to maintain normal serum calcium, which leads to increased renal reabsorption of calcium. This compensatory mechanism results in lower urinary calcium excretion. High urine calcium would be inconsistent with the body's attempt to conserve calcium in this condition.
  • ➤ The core problem in nutritional rickets is the body's inability to absorb and utilize calcium and phosphorus effectively.
  • ➤ The body compensates by increasing PTH to maintain normal serum calcium, which leads to increased renal reabsorption of calcium.
  • ➤ This compensatory mechanism results in lower urinary calcium excretion.
  • ➤ High urine calcium would be inconsistent with the body's attempt to conserve calcium in this condition.

questions.text: Indications for surgery (including biopsy) in a patient with Potts spine are all except:
questions.correct_answer: B. Cold abscess without neurological involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cold abscess without neurological involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While surgery is often necessary for Pott's spine, a cold abscess without neurological involvement can often be managed with medical treatment alone.
  • ➤ While surgery is often necessary for Pott's spine, a cold abscess without neurological involvement can often be managed with medical treatment alone.

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker falls from a ladder, landing on his outstretched right hand. He complains of severe pain in his right wrist and forearm. On examination, there is significant swelling and tenderness over the distal radius and at the wrist. Radiographs are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Galeazzi fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The defining feature of a Galeazzi fracture is the combination of a distal radius fracture and disruption of the DRUJ. This is what distinguishes it from other wrist and forearm fractures.
  • ➤ The defining feature of a Galeazzi fracture is the combination of a distal radius fracture and disruption of the DRUJ.
  • ➤ This is what distinguishes it from other wrist and forearm fractures.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of delayed development and frequent fractures. His parents report that he has had multiple fractures with minimal trauma and that he has had difficulty walking. On physical examination, the child appears to be shorter than his peers, and his face has a “moon-shaped” appearance. Laboratory results show normal calcium and phosphorus levels. A radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marble bone disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of frequent fractures, increased bone density on X-ray, and craniofacial abnormalities in a young child strongly suggests osteopetrosis.
  • ➤ The combination of frequent fractures, increased bone density on X-ray, and craniofacial abnormalities in a young child strongly suggests osteopetrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of progressive pain in his right hip over the past 6 months. He reports that the pain is deep, aching, and worsens with weight-bearing activities. The pain has gradually become constant, and he now experiences difficulty with ambulation. He has a history of long-term steroid use for autoimmune disease and a past history of alcohol abuse. On examination, there is limited range of motion in the right hip, particularly with internal rotation and abduction, and the patient reports pain with these movements. X-rays show crescent sign and subchondral sclerosis of the femoral head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Avascular necrosis of the hip
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Avascular Necrosis of the Hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The history of long-term steroid use, alcohol abuse, progressive hip pain, limited range of motion, and the radiographic finding of the crescent sign strongly suggest avascular necrosis of the hip.
  • ➤ The history of long-term steroid use, alcohol abuse, progressive hip pain, limited range of motion, and the radiographic finding of the crescent sign strongly suggest avascular necrosis of the hip.

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic due to difficulty moving the right arm. The mother reports that during delivery, there was shoulder dystocia, and the baby’s right arm was extended above the head while the shoulder was impacted. On physical examination, the right arm is held in a internal rotation of the shoulder, extension at the elbow, and pronation of the forearm. The infant is unable to lift the right arm and has decreased sensation over the lateral aspect of the right arm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Erb's Palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erb’s palsy (Erb-Duchenne palsy) is caused by an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5-C6), which commonly occurs due to excessive lateral traction on the neck during delivery, especially in cases of shoulder dystocia.
  • ➤ Erb’s palsy (Erb-Duchenne palsy) is caused by an injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5-C6), which commonly occurs due to excessive lateral traction on the neck during delivery, especially in cases of shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient suffers with Intracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemiarthroplasty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intracapsular fractures have a high risk of AVN, which hemiarthroplasty addresses. Hemiarthroplasty provides pain relief and allows for faster rehabilitation.
  • ➤ Intracapsular fractures have a high risk of AVN, which hemiarthroplasty addresses.
  • ➤ Hemiarthroplasty provides pain relief and allows for faster rehabilitation.
